thread.title: Tech review: Speakers are designed to go with you on waves or a bike
thread.title_full: Tech review: Speakers are designed to go with you on waves or a bike | Dallas Morning News

author: JIM ROSSMAN
title: Tech review: Speakers are designed to go with you on waves or a bike
text:
I’m always a little delighted to find new categories of tech products I didn’t know I needed.
True, not many tech products are really “needed,” but it’s always nice to find a product that fills a specific purpose and then realize there are similar products in that same category.
Today we’re looking at two portable Bluetooth speakers that are both rugged and waterproof — the Braven BRV-Pro ($149.99, www.braven.com ) and the Altec Lansing LifeJacket 2 ($149.99, www.alteclansing.com ).
Do some comparison-shopping before you buy, as I saw some lower pricing from Amazon.
In reading about these speakers, I’ve seen them compared to GoPro cameras in that they can be mounted to a bike or even a surfboard for use during your favorite recreational activity.
To be honest, I’ve never seen a speaker mounted to someone’s bike or surfboard, but maybe I just don’t hang out with the right people.
These Bluetooth speakers have features in common besides their price.
Braven BRV-Pro
I’ve been a fan of Braven Bluetooth speakers for a long time, and the BRV-Pro is no exception.
The speaker measures 6.4 by 1.5 by 2.8 inches and weighs 1.44 lbs.
It can play up to 15 hours of music with its rechargeable lithium-ion battery.
The BRV-Pro is IPX7 waterproof, and it has a built-in microphone so you can use it as a speakerphone with a connected smartphone.
Controls on the speaker consist of four buttons on top, volume up and down buttons (they also act as skip ahead/skip back for music tracks if you press and hold), a play/pause button and a power button.
The play/pause button also acts to accept or hang up calls.
The Braven BRV-Pro has a removable top plate so you can mount accessories such as a larger battery, LED light, stacking plate (so you can group two or more speakers for more sound), a solar panel (for all-day playing/charging) and an action mount that enables you to put the speaker on most GoPro-compatible action mounts.
The ports of the BRV-Pro live under a hinged-door with a secure latching system. For the speaker to survive water, the door must be closed and no cables can be connected.
Under the door are a microUSB port for charging the battery, a 3.5 mm aux-in port and a full-size USB port that is used to charge portable electronics like your phone from the speaker’s battery.
I did find the BRV-Pro would turn itself on when paired with my iPhone 6s. I’d turn it off, and a few minutes later it would power back on again.
It was a bit strange. The powering on stopped when I unpaired the phone and speaker.
Pros: Small, rugged, easy to use, nice accessories
Cons: Small sound, expensive
Bottom Line: Waterproof is good, but Braven has other speakers that sound better if you can keep them dry.
Altec Lansing LifeJacket 2
I’ve known about the Altec Lansing audio brand for years, but this is my first experience with the Bluetooth speakers.
The LifeJacket 2 is a beefy speaker, weighing in at 2 pounds and measuring 7.5 by 3.12 by 2.82 inches.
The speaker is IP67 rated to be waterproof, sand-proof, snow-proof, dustproof, shockproof, and it floats.
The LifeJacket 2 has a built-in voice that clearly states the unit is powering on or off and when it’s paired. I couldn’t find a way to disable the voice status updates, which is a bit annoying.
There are only three buttons on the top of the LifeJacket 2, volume up and down and a power button that also accepts or ends calls and invokes Siri (press three times).
Around back, a small rubber door conceals the microUSB (charging port), aux-in and USB port for charging your phone.
Like the Braven, the LifeJacket 2 is only waterproof if you have the port door closed and sealed.
On the bottom is a one-fourth-inch threaded accessory mount point. My LifeJacket 2 came with a handlebar mount, but it should also work with any other action mount with a one-fourth-inch threaded screw, like a tripod mount.
Pros: Very tough, dust proof, included mount
Cons: Big, heavy.
Bottom Line: Seems to be ready for anything you can throw at it.
Real-life use
The speakers are remarkably similar, but they do have some differences.
The Altec Lansing is dustproof while the Braven is not.
I’ve listed each speaker’s IP (ingress protection) rating.
The Braven’s IPX7 rating means no dust or solid object protection, but it’s protected against water immersion up to 1 meter deep.
The LifeJacket 2’s IP67 means totally protected against dust and water immersion up to 1 meter.
Wireless range for playing music was pretty similar, despite there being a big difference in stated range.
The Braven lists up to 100 feet of range in its specs, while the LifeJacket 2 lists 33 feet as its range.
I tested both speakers outside my office by pairing each with my phone, setting the phone on the trunk of a car in the parking lot and walking away until the signal started breaking up.
The Braven’s range outside with a clear line of sight was about 200 feet, while the LifeJacket 2’s range was about 160 feet. Both speakers worked well past their stated ranges, and both would work across most backyards.
I can see these speakers being popular poolside.
How do they sound?
It’s pretty easy to compare the sound of both speakers. I paired each speaker with my iPhone and started some music. It’s a simple on-screen selection to change between the speakers during a song, so I could flip between them mid-song and get a good feel for the sound.
What did I find?
It’s about a draw.
Some music sounded better on the Braven, while other songs sounded better on the LifeJacket 2.
I liked Pink Floyd better on the LifeJacket 2, but Dire Straits sounded better on the BRV-Pro.
Neither has any tone adjustments, so you’ll have to adjust the sound on your source player.
Neither of these speakers should be your only sound system, as you’ll be disappointed, but they sound good enough for a pool party, tailgate party or campsite.
I’d have to give the edge to the Altec Lansing LifeJacket 2 for being a bit more rugged and including a handlebar mount, although I do like the accessories that are available for the Braven.
The optional flashlight, spare battery and solar panel make the Braven a better choice for campers.
